I've noticed that both os.remove and subprocess.check_call have been used to remove files in our code even though os.remove is more popular. I am reading that both have pros and cons with more cons for os.remove due to unreliability. The best practice for os.remove or os.unlink is to first check if the file exists or not. You can catch not existing file in the try block as you show, but to me both ways are doing the job. What is the gain to make this change?

I think we don't need "^" since we use re.match() at L.305 which only matches at the beginning of the string.
https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html#re.match

Good point. I replaced re.match by re.search so that we can define whole patterns explicitly instead of relying on implicit rules implemented in the function.

Another possible option is to use fullmatch to remove both ^ and $, but I prefer having both defined in pattern string so that we can be more aware of the whole pattern.

> How often is this going to run? Is it OK to repeatedly patch the
 > admin user with this option? Why not do this in the
 > openstack::keystone::bootstrap class, which should only be run
 > once?

Yes it is OK to repeatedly patch the users' options. We may need to patch services users to update their options as well in near future, by the time of keystone bootstrap, these users are not created.

Further more, in keystone::bootstrap, there is a dependency condition (Class[$name] -> Class['::platform::client']), but the scripts need platform::client to run first to setup openrc.
One more thing I'd like to mention, that user can make the same PATCH call to reset this user option to false (which we don't want), the sysinv audit will correct it in this case.

I like the idea of using an external system to store the history.

I wonder if it will be efficient enough to make an external API call every time there's a policy change.  Or are you thinking we would write to a file on local disk on every policy change and then move that file to the external service periodically?

How would this work once there are multiple policy-engines for HA/HT?  Is there just one that records the policy violations?  

Perhaps we could implement this by having each policy violation cause an action to be executed and use whatever mechanism we've chosen to ensure only one PE writes to the history.

Storing the rows in the tables marked as 'history' makes sense.  

What about the rules that make those rows true?  What about the data you need to use with those rows?  

More generally, what is the use case we are targeting here?  Would someone just looking at the history of violations have all the information they need?  Or would they also want the rules that were in force, and maybe the data that was necessary to generate the violation row.

See comments above about HA/HT.  

I like the idea of having a history service that just subscribes to the appropriate tables.

I don't think of the "history" flag as being a property of a rule.  I think of it as being a property of an entire table, which could be defined using multiple rules.

I think we'd probably want a separate mysql database table that records which datalog tables we want to store the history for.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: better to take it as json file or something? , its difficult to express on command line?

In existing drivers, the schema is fixed in the code and not stored separately in database. Per-datasource configurations like datasource name and auth url are stored in the database and used to re-create the datasource instance when syncing to a replica node or when Congress restarts.

In the generic driver, the schema is not fix by the driver but instead varies from one datasource instance to another, using the same driver. So the schema becomes a datasource instance configuration similar to datasource name and auth url. These pieces of information needed to create a datasource from the driver are stored in the database.

So it makes sense to allow for specifying schema in file, but it'd change and complicate the model we have today to require the schema file when the datasource instance is re-created (same node or different node). Instead, the database should continue to contain all the information required to re-create the datasource instance.

So after thinking it through, people can use standard unix shell (example in bash) to do:
openstack congress datasource create generic_push_driver vitrage --config schema="$(< schemafile.json)"

Seems redundant and counter to the unix philosophy to add special code in our command to do something already built in to the shell.
we don't store the schema in database right? its in memory computation?

That's a good idea: thinking about accepting the config as file in addition to command-line. We'd need to think a bit about how to do it though. Entering file path as config param doesn't really make sense because the config is stored in database for datasource instantiation on other nodes. We'd need to create a new mechanism to pass file path and have the content be read.

But now that I say that, it seems the user can easily use standard unix shell to feed the file content into this command without us doing anything special. What do you think?

this only works if the pushed data is only have columns with plain values, but doesn't support incase if any column has dict, which i have seen in many cases. with generic driver, we cant support complex schemas right, user would face difficulty in expressing them?

Right. This is designed for the case of source pushing rows. Not intended for complex objects that translates to to multiple rows in multiple tables. We can extend it in the future, but I think it already covers most of the needed cases. Basically we're asking the source to send us rows instead of nested objects.
Ok, Thanks
why the remove is required? whenever someone pushes the data, policy will be immediately gets evaluated, so removing the data doesn't have any use?

Ah I misunderstood your original question. I thought you were asking why we need remove in addition to add. But really you're asking why we need remove/add in addition to PUT (setting entire table at once). That is, why not just always get the entire new state at once instead of supporting PATCH. Is that right?

I'll explain my understanding in three points below why we want to support PATCH in addition to PUT.

1. Congress needs the entire state to correctly evaluate policy. In case of alarms, one might think we need to know only about the new alarms triggered and respond to them, and we can ignore any old information about alarms that had been triggered earlier. But that only holds for the simplest policies. In something slightly more complex, one may have a policy that says "send phone alert if there is two or more alarms of high severity". In that case, suppose the first alarm activates at 10:00, then the next alarm activates at 10:05, Congress needs both the new and the old information to recognize there are two alarms on.
We might say the source should just send all the information relevant to evaluating the policy, but the source doesn't know what policy is declared on congress side.
If we think about the general case beyond alarms, it becomes even clearer. The generic datasource driver can be used for any information represented in tables, not just alarms. For example, a particular use may have a table of users and their contact information for purpose of directing alerts. Clearly, congress needs to whole list of users, not just the users added in the most recent update.


2. Because that's how the sources communicate.
For efficiency, some/many sources are architected in a way that processes changes in state rather than the whole state. Vitrage, for example, processes changes in base alarm states by propagating those changes to the derived alarm states, then sends notifications of those changes. At that point in the processing, vitrage doesn't retrieve any information about alarms that didn't change because it has no need to. So it cannot send Congress the entire new state, only the changes (Add this row, delete this row, add this row, etc.).

3. Because it's more efficient. If there are 1000 users represented in a table, and 10 users are added/deleted, it is obviously more efficient for all components involved to send the change rather than the whole new state. For publishing from the datasource instance to the policy engine, congress also takes a differential approach where the information about which rows are added and which rows are deleted is sent.

----

On the clean-up question, it's the same situation as polling datasources. Congress just goes with whatever information we get from the source. Each time the source updates Congress, the source can choose to send the changes using PATCH or send a new snapshot using PUT. So if the source behaves correctly, Congress should stay sync'ed to the source without any need for special clean-up. For added safety, we could allow in the schema an optional maximum number of rows for each table. Then we'd need to decide how to respond when that number is reached. Deleting the oldest rows could make sense. Future work maybe?

Policy evaluations are based on the state, where both the presence and absence of tuples. For example, an admin might have a policy that says to do something whenever alarm X is active but no other alarm of the same type is active. Also add+remove is another way to update a row, say to change the state of an alarm from active to inactive. Aside from action triggers, someone looking at the states in a monitoring panel would want the updated information.

The general idea is that we use congress tables to represent the most up-to-date state of the data center, and that information can be consumed by various decision engines, policy engines, monitoring engines, users, etc.

sorry, still couldnt get why remove would be useful . But when someone pushes data to congress, it will immediately gets published to PE for evaluation right? so what you meant is every time whole table data would be published, old+new rows into PE?
For pushing isn't it more relevant to update entire data instead because once policy gets evaluated mostly data would not be needed, because pushing generally done to evaluate particular data at that point of time violates any policy rather than historic data which in most of the cases irrelevant.

One more question, do we plan to cleanup the rows from time to time in push type datasource, otherwise in memory space would be increased indefinitely every time? and also policy evaluation would get cumbersome if you plan to send to entire table data?

congress/datasources/designate_driver.py.message: Here I just added the zone_id field as a column to produce the expected output: 2150b1bf-dee2-4221-b162-562bc6096648

Instead of using id-col, I changed it to parent-key instead.
Basically, id-col generates an id in the parent table (RECORDSETS in this case) to point to associated rows in the child table (RECORDS in this case), which is the reason why a new ID shows up in the actual output in the third column of RECORDSETS.

Changing it to parent-key instead eliminates this extra column in the parent table, but instead creates a new first column in the child table to point back to the associated row in the parent table.

You can read more about what each does here:
parent-key: https://github.com/openstack/congress/blob/master/congress/datasources/datasource_driver.py#L94
id-col: https://github.com/openstack/congress/blob/master/congress/datasources/datasource_driver.py#L107
could you please why is it required to convert to dict explicitly. If it returns object , you can use DOT_SELECTOR which is convenient?
carmine, same comment as prev patch, can you explain why is it needed, what issue you are facing without it?

this check is necessary 'cause in the unit test, zone is created like a dict and not like an object. But in the unit test, the update method tries to applicate dict attribute to a dict (permission denied) and it will be an error, so without this check the unit test will fail.

I think the better way would be updating unit test to return object instead as required by this function, instead of changing the function itself. For reference , you can check here https://github.com/openstack/congress/blob/master/congress/tests/datasources/test_heatv1_driver.py#L100

neutron_tempest_plugin/scenario/base.py.message: nit: i think most distros these days have a unified ping binary, where both ping4 and ping6 can be used, each forcing the correct address family.  Don't know if cirros uses this convention though.

You're right Brian: for Cirros the ping command works both for IPv6 and IPv4.

example taken from Cirros 0.5.1

$ ping fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178
PING fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178 (fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178: seq=0 ttl=64 time=11.612 ms
64 bytes from fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178: seq=1 ttl=64 time=0.603 ms
64 bytes from fe80::f816:3eff:fe9f:c178: seq=2 ttl=64 time=0.516 m
I guess you still could have used ping4 here, which will force ping to use an AF_INET lookup.
I can modify this to use ping in all cases.

From Cirros ping help page:
        -W SEC          Seconds to wait for the first response (default:10)
                        (after all -c CNT packets are sent)
        -w SEC          Seconds until ping exits (default:infinite)
                        (can exit earlier with -c CNT)


With this change the OVN tests started to pass, as cirros ping doesn't timeout on waiting for AAAA responses.
My only concern with this internally these options affect different parts of the ping source code, and it's unclear if it could cause other issues.  The descriptions of both are pretty terrible imo.

doc/source/sm_db/sm_db_terminology.rst.message:
There are 2 different views of the service configuration.

static view, services are organized as service groups, each service has its static configurations (services table), dependencies (service_dependency table), actions (service_actions table)

From runtime view, services are deployed by service domain (although we have only 1 domain). A node on which "controller" domain is deployed is a controller node. A system has multiple nodes (nodes table), each domain has its peer(s) (service_domain_neighbors table). Services are scheduled by service domain member and current assignment (scheduling) is stored in service_domain_assignments table, each service is managed as a service instance (service_instances table), this means that multiple service instances of the same service can be run at the same time. similarly, a service group can be scheduled in multiple service domains

Done

Added under index.rst, same directory
Failure of service with impact of Minor, Major and Critical will result controller "warning", "degraded" and "failure" respectively.
